title: By when will more than 15,000,000 COVID-19 tests have been conducted in the United States?
preds: 15 M tests have been conducted on May 26th

The outcome of this one hasn't been in doubt for a few weeks; we passed 15M tests today.  But the numbers for the past two days have been on the low side.  If this dip had happened earlier it could have moved the finish line into June.  It just goes to show that it doesn't pay to ever be too certain.
Average of ~400,000 tests a day and today on 5/26 we're just about 400,000 shy of 15m. Nothing is 100%, though.
Per Covid tracking project we are at 14.6 million tests on 5/25.
25/5/20, total tests 14,779,172 at time of writing

13.4 million as of 5/22. To get 1.6 million tests in 9 days, we would need an average of 177k tests per day. Right now, we're averaging like 400k per day. I'd call it a certainty that we reach 15 million by the end of the month.

Per COVID tracking project we are at 13.98million and per CDC we are at 13.6 million. At least 200k tests being done daily and with 9 days left, we will cross 15m by end of May either the 30th or the 31st

The daily trend is high-likely stay in the range of [0.029 - 0.047], total tests will reach 15 million between 25 and 26 of May. https://github.com/owid/covid-19-data/blob/master/public/data/owid-covid-data.xlsx
Still tracking up as expected following parabolic curve.
Recent trend is well described by a parabolic fit, predicting to hit target by May25.
12,647,791 as of 5/20. ~350-400k additional tests per day for the past week.
On track to reach 15M on May 26, or maybe one day before.

The number of tests per day ranges between 304k to 403k in last 8 days.. In remaining 11 days it will add 3.3 million tests As per COVID tracking project, 12.23 million tests have been done as of May 20th. This adds to over 15 million.
So I will revise the  numbers today

12,233,987 as of 5/19 leaves 2,766,013, last 10 day average ~350K/day = 8 days which puts it at 5/27, so 4 days wiggle room to stay within May, which is most likely given the increase in daily numbers, BUT still close enough that a handful of days with lower averages or some unforeseen event (like the tests or the results come into question as to accuracy, lab issue, etc.) still leave a slight possibility it could go into June.

At current moving average rate should be within monthly of May. Enormous effort to scale up testing. So unless there’s a supply chain breakdown or other unforeseen bottleneck it will happen this month. Odds of that happening should be reasonably less than 1/200 - otherwise downright incompetence
I have hindsight for the first option as I am doing this on may 18. As of May 18th 11.8 million. So in next few days we should be able to perform  3.3million divided by 12 ie 300k tests a day
I'll overcompensate for my previous pessimistic assessments.
Quite likely to reach the 15M by 31 May based on recent increase in daily test number
Should reach this figure by end of may

11 million tests as of 5/16. Even if we account for a wide range of 300k to 400k tests per day, we can expect to hit 15 million in something like 10-14 days. Should be pretty comfortably before June 1, but there's always a chance that testing dips consistently over the next couple weeks.
Looks like May is the winner. On to 400K and then to 1M tests per day. We need the testing so we know who is infected. Currently we don't.;

The 15 mn test threshold will at current rate of new tests (with a slight growth to 400,000 new tests per day on average)  likely be hit on 27 or 28 May 2020. Edit: with the 4d-average 18 to 21 May 2020 above 400,000 per day, the 15mn tests will be surpassed at 26 May 2020 at latest.
update 16/05. US now getting its act together and testing 300,000/day. Current total tests from CDC 10,200,000. As testing ramps up further will likely reach 15M by end May. Or may just miss this.

The number of tests has risen almost exactly along the trajectory I predicted 2 weeks ago with a linear increase in new tests per day and a parabolic increase in total tests. According to my equation, May 27 will be the first day with 15 million tests. Even if the number of new tests per day remains fixed at this point, 15 million will be surpassed by the end of May. Since this is very close to the end of June and there remains a chance of a testing slowdown, I am increasing my confidence but still keeping it below 90%.

Need 274,013 tests per day on average from now until the end of May to have 15 million. Over the past two weeks, the average is roughly 289,000, and in just the past week it is 316,000. Add in the fact that every politician is incentivized to increase testing to re-open safely, and before May 31 is a fairly safe bet.

Updating forecast because daily testing has topped 300,000 the last four days straight and the trend continues up. Previously calculated ~283,000 tests per day needed to hit 15,000,000 in May and that is being exceeded, high chance we hit 15,000,000 in May.

Ok the math works for May. I am sometimes too timid.
Looks like total testing should reach goal by end of May.
Testing continues to improve haltingly. It's likely to be right on the bubble, but the May side of it. Fingers crossed.

At time of forecast 5,651,542 tests remain to hit 15,000,000 based on numbers as of May 11. Latest daily test numbers range from ~250,000 to ~390,000. The latest day was 390,000 and was the highest single day testing by far. To hit 15 million in May leaves 20 days of testing resulting in ~283,000 tests per day. Based on recent testing numbers and the large testing numbers on May 11 and the steady upward trend in tests per day I think 15 million is most likely to be achieved in late May.
I used quarter-ruled graph paper, entered the data, then extended the line. . . .

Slightly re-adjusted because average went up pretty significantly recently, with more like 250k average. That puts 15m back at the very beginning of June, so equally as possible averages will increase enough to be reached in May as something happens to supply chain, labs, something unexpected that pushes to beyond June.
Should reach 15M somewhere between May 25 and May 27, unless there is a surprise.

+2% to 5/1-5/31, -2% to 6/1-6/30. After today (394.7k new tests), if the daily tests stay flat at the five day average (319k), the seven day average (300k), or the 10 day (283k) then the US will reach 15 million total tests by month end. The growth in new tests would have to turn negative otherwise.

The number of tests in the US has gone from 2.24 million to 8.1 million since April of 2020. If this trend continues the US will exceed 15 million tests by the end of May.

I'm updating a previous forecast.
This time I just I just made a curve of the data in Excel and then used the polynomial "best fit curve" to extend out until it hit 15 million cases (which was near May 30).  Without doing better stats, It's hard to predict the likelihood of hitting before vs after May 31. The curve looks like it will hit slightly before so I'm overweighting in that direction.
Three consecutive days of 300k+ tests has caused the crowd to begin to flip.  There aren't many points to be had going forward, unless of course there is a surprise waiting to happen.

At the current number of tests per day (Apr 22-May 8), there will be around 14 million tests by May 31. Contact tracing efforts such as those in New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut (and hopefully other states) should increase that to above 15 million by May 31, though it will be close.
Now demonstrating ablity to do more testing on a regular basis, May is back on the table in my book.

Later than my first forecast on 4/10 because per day increases have been slower and smaller. I dropped my average of 250k/day to 200k/day and with 6.55 million tests given so far, it comes to about 42 days from now, which is mid-June. It’s unlikely but possible something could happen to accelerate that all the way back into May, but it’s more likely it would take longer than go faster.

1500000 minus the tests and dividing by the average tests done the last week and then the same, but the average for the last 3 weeks gives between 61 and 80 days left. Finally if we take the increase in tests between the two averages and assume a linear increase into the next 3 weeks. Would give 280k tests a day on average. In this scenario one would hit 15000000 in around 32 days. This means that a minimum of June 1 and a maximum of July 31 is likely.

It's still a horse race between May and June.  I've placed my bets equally. Perhaps I'll pick a winner a little later.
Testing is so inconsistent ---- that makes this a challenge.

If we'll see 250,000 tests by day on average in the next 30 days, there will be more than 15,000,000 tests conducted at the beginning of May. It may get really close. Let's see the development over the next week.

If the number of tests per day remains fixed at the current rate of ~250,000 per day, over 15 million total tests will have been conducted by the first week of June. It is unlikely the rate of testing will decrease as there are still more people who need a test than can get one. Therefore reaching the 15 million milestone before July and August is virtually certain. If the rate of testing per day continues to increase linearly, as it has roughly done so far, then over 15 million tests will be completed by the end of May. Continued increasing in the number of tests seems most likely.

As of April 20th, increase in total tests (7-day rolling average) is 4.7% [total tests today are 4.7% more than yesterday.] Total tests on April 20 is 3,893,815 per link below. There has been a very smooth day-to-day increase in total number of tests since March 26 (see link below). If there is a sudden increase in test production this will obviously change.  https://www.statista.com/statistics/1111631/cumulative-number-of-covid19-tests-carried-out-in-the-us/ at 5% = 15,185,878 in 58 days
at 4% = 15,108,002 in 72 days It will take between 58 (5%) and 72 (4%) days from Apr 20, 2020. So sometime between June 17 and July 1. Since there should be an acceleration of test kits available will target June 24 (65 days) as the date US reaches 15,000,000 total tests. The recent Harvard paper on TTSI (Test, Trace, Supported Isolation) requires 5 million tests per day initially to begin to open up and 20 million per day  for getting back to "normal."   https://ethics.harvard.edu/files/center-for-ethics/files/roadmaptopandemicresilience_updated_4.20.20.pdf

The Brier score is very asymmetrical.  You get penalized a lot for being very wrong, but there's not much extra reward for being very right vs mostly right.  This is something I often forget when assigning probabilities.  Note to self: "don't go all in, this ain't Texas hold'em."

Currently the U.S. is conducting 1.5/2 million tests per week and is planning to double its capacity in the coming weeks. Assuming that tests are still in production for 3 weeks and that during those 3 weeks the average conducted tests are 1.75 million, we reach May 16th with a total of 10.5 million tests conducted in total. One factor we have to take into consideration is that the costs of these tests are decreasing, or at least they will be, and they will be made more accessible. The combination of easier accessibility, lower cost, and increased screening lead me to believe that the U.S. will pass 15 million testa by the end of May. However, having seen the lack of a national guideline on testing different perspectives may slow down testing and its efficiency which is why  also consider the first week and a half a plausible date for the passing of the threshold.

Helpful spreadsheet @dglid Daily test count's rising fast. 35 days to May 31= 285k/day avg till then. Last 4 days we've had a 250k average. The mayhem of the last six weeks won't be as bad in the next 3-4 weeks. Supply Chains and Solutions are now getting their games on... I am pleased by this and hope the growth continues. 3,081,620 has been tested by 14 April.  About 150k tests are done per day.
To reach 15M with 100k per day takes 119 days, putting it in the not before August basket.
To reach 15M with 125k per day takes 95 days, putting it in the July basket.
To reach 15M with 150k per day takes 80 days, putting it in the July basket.
To reach 15M with 175k per day takes 68 days, putting it in the June basket.
To reach 15M with 200k per day takes 60 days, putting it in the June basket. Testing is supposed to increase as more are available and all the kinks worked out, so I give the June basket a bit more than the July basket.
spreading the risk as this question's components and the surrounding news develops...
Throughout April, the number of tests have been 150 000 a day and so that will be my base, with a chance for a rapid increase in testing, but seeing it as unlikely that it will decrease.

It would take a step function increase in test rates to reach 15M before May 1; reducing the chance of that to zero.  But the number of daily tests has trended down for the past week.  While I'm still overweighting May, I'm reducing the overweight to 53%.

Interesting Politico Live Tracker:
https://www.politico.com/interactives/2020/coronavirus-testing-by-state-chart-of-new-cases/
However from The Atlantics and Stat News above, it seems that a variety of obstacles can hinder a continuation of the testing trend (roughly locating 15M somewhere in June), let alone an exponential growth of the number of tests conducted.

The main is that at this point COVID Tracking Project is tracking RNA testing of SARS-CoV-2. This forecast takes into account only this kind of testing. My assumption is that over late spring and summer, number of tests, which is now based mostly on testing moderate to severe COVID conditions, will be going down due to social distancing and, to lesser extent, seasonal nature of coronavirus. My estimate is that the number of tests (according to my logistic model) will be between 6 to 7 million. The real number of infections, if asymptomatic and mild cases are included, of course, is much higher, but due to limiting factors - number of kits, equipment, PPE, trained lab personnel... - it is not reflected in number of performed tests.  When testing based on "need" as described above will go down, the other form of testing will pick up - testing all suspects including mild cases and contacts - the precondition to open the economy. You would think, with widely accessible testing, these numbers will go up and up and up. But South Korea’s experience shows the opposite - testing goes significantly down after the outbreak is subdued. There is always a background of colds, but these ones fall during summer. With significantly less new mild, moderate and severe cases, less testing is needed for potential (asymptomatic) suspects as well. I expect it will not exceed number of tests based on “need”. So, it will be less than 15 million by August 1st. There is a hidden danger though – another kind of “COVID tests” will be widely available soon – serological tests for antiviral antibodies and viral antigens. They will be cheaper and in theory can be used for diagnosis – especially early antigens and (IgM) antibodies– but they are less sensitive: antigens appear first in blood, then IgM antibodies, then IgG antibodies. And it requires more time for specimens become positive – days for antigens in blood, close to a week for IgM and two weeks or more for IgG - to become detectable. And it is in blood, requiring a blood draw or a prick to get a sample. So RNA testing of nasopharyngeal swabs will remain a gold standard - COVID-19 starts as a disease of respiratory system after all.
But it will reveal a real (huge) number of SARS-CoV-2 infections – by picking up past infections when looking at the late IgG antibodies. If serological tests for this purpose are included in “COVID-19 tests”, the latter can get a huge boost. Then my forecast can become huge underestimation. The interesting thing is that most probably, it will be not a nation-wide effort as the administration is not interested in how many people have been really infected - it is bad for reelection. So it is known unknown that is hard to predict. And will this number be reportable and included in "COVID tests" anyway?
The US Government is not perpared for this scale - especially not Mr. Trump.

Currently around 150k test on average per day -> this would lead to end of June.
Since significant scale-up is required the daily test will increase given current testings.
New approaches will increase the laboratory capacities (pool testing of several probes etc.) and new antibody tests will increase daily rate significantly. But production of these new test will take time to ramp-up, so scale-up in April unlikely.

I'm using data from this site: https://ourworldindata.org/covid-testing My stats knowledge is weak so I figured out a compound growth number, figured out the standard deviation of that and did 3 projections to get a range of dates around my version of a 90% confidence interval. I got a daily growth factor that was far smaller than most people: ~2% It's very sensitive to what day you choose to start the analysis so I tried to choose it once the major leaps up stopped. My numbers put me smack dab in May 31/June1 which makes me wish the categories were written differently. Also gives me 95% chance of landing somewhere within 1 month on either side of that date. Seems overly narrow so I'm probably doing something wrong statistically.

Quant's HELP! comments or improvements.....that should be easy!   :-)  I made a simple spreadsheet (I'm a simpleton) with today's base of 2.8mm tested and 150,00 tests a day and added a 10% Daily Testing Growth Rate. You hit 15mm tests at Day 44 and that day you tested 900,000 folks. That's May 24th. Same math at 5% growth is Day 85 with about 450,000 tested. you're there by day about July 5th I'm guessing it'll be somewhere in the middle... so far. HOW MANY TESTS BECOME AVAILABLE AND HOW DISTRIBUTED WILL BE THE REAL PUZZLE TO SOLVE FOR.

5-day average: 148k
10-day average: 150k Further base lines:
650k average per day until 30 April -> 15mn reached on 30 April
250k average per day until 31 May -> 15mn reached on 31 May
155k average per day until 30 June -> 15mn reached on 30 June
112k average per day until 31 July ->  15mn reached on 31 July Reasons for ealier:
- testing rates have increased significantly since mid March, it doesn't look like the peak has been reached
- re-opening the economy will require even more testing
- currently some capacities still unused due to regulatory constraints but working on solutions (https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-020-01068-3)
- government communicating that there will be more testing capacities in May (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-11/u-s-testing-capacity-in-ballpark-for-may-reopening-czar-says?sref=rCENjUdc)
- scientists are working on new tests which could help increase the capacity (https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-020-00827-6) Reasons for later:
- growth rate of tests has stabilized recently (5-day average below 10d average but could be Easter effect)
- bureaucratic hurdles will not disappear overnight
- lack of supplies creates hurdles for further scaling up

There are lots of logistics that have to be in place to enable more testing -- swabs, test kits, chemical reagents, laboratories, and skilled lab technicians.  If any one is missing the test rate cannot increase.  The number of tests was increasing at a fast exponential rate (nearly doubling every 2 days) throughout the month of March, until the 27th.  Since then the rate of increase has slowed, but it's still going up.  It seems unlikely that 15M tests will be done by May 1, so I'll go with the crowd and wager a 2% chance. If the test rate levels off at 150k/day we will reach 15M by early July.  That seems like a worst case possibility.  If the number of tests continues to increase at a rate of 2.5% per day we will get to 15M before the end of May, with a few days to spare.  I'm going to overweight this optimistic case at 57%.  That is WAY more optimistic than the crowd, which is only at 12%.  If the test rate flattens I will have to revise the forecast, or I'll get killed on the Brier score.  Hey, it's better than getting killed by the virus.  Stay well.

Currently the average number of tests is growing at a (smoothed) ~5% p.d. though this has been rapidly dropping as absolute numbers grow. This models an exponential decay from ~5% going forward with the number of tests per day peaking around ~300k (assumes no upper limits on capacity below this mark) at the end of May / beginning of June and ~0.2% growth at this time.

Currently testing 150,000 per day with 2,666,000 tests to date. 15,000,000 will be achieved in 90 days unless testing rate is increased.  Motivation for increasing the rate of testing may come from the desire to open the economy.

Total tests grew about 1 million last week. As of today, there have been 2.6 million total tests. Total tests grew about 1 million the week before last as well.  # of weeks until:  May 1: 3 - implies about 4 million tests a week
May 31: 7 - implies 1.7 million tests a week
June 30: 11.5 - implies 1.1 million tests a week
July 31: 16 - implies .8 million tests per week.  To me, this suggests that the likely time we reach 15 million is around end of June, early July. The number of tests has not been growing exponentially or really much at all, so it seems likely that we reach 15 million tests around June/July.

Para el día 30 de marzo “… the United States had just run five tests per million” teniendo un total de 328,2 millones de habitantes en el país el año 2019. Eso equivale a un total de 1641 tests efectuados. Sin embargo, hay que tener en cuanta que el país no estaba trabajando con su máximo potencial en torno a esta enfermedad. 
Además, el día 28 de marzo se anunció que desde una semana más adelante se "... espera la fabricación de cerca de cinco millones de test al mes”. Por lo tanto, suponiendo que estos tests logran ser producidos y utilizados en el país, en menos de tres meses (abril, mayo y junio) el país habría superado la realización de 15 millones de tests. 
Sin embrago, como se podría estar tanto subestimando la capacidad de desarrollo de tests de corona virus, como sobrestimando, no puedo atribuirle todas las probabilidades de cumplir con los 15 millones de tests de corona virus al mes de junio. https://hbr.org/2020/03/why-is-the-u-s-behind-on-coronavirus-testing

2,538,888 tests have been done by the 11th of April. The CDC reported doing about 100-150,000 tests a day. https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-updates/testing-in-us.html Doing 12,5 million tests with 100,000 tests a day: 125 days
Doing 12,5 million tests with 200,000 tests a day: 62,5 days
Doing 12,5 million tests with 300,000 tests a day: 42 days As there has been no signifcant increase in the number of tests a day,  I go with the first two options and try to shoot for the median.

Basic linear model [1] that projects out test count based on average test growth over last 7 days. Projected mean: 6/29/20
Standard deviation: 26 days (i.e. 68% of the time result will be within this many days of either side of projected mean) Model projections: 1%, 13%, 39%, 36%, 11%
Extremized [2]: 1%, 11%, 47%, 31%, 10%
Crowd: 2%, 35%, 61%, 1%, 1% It's early, so I don't want to put too much weight into the crowd, but the fact that they are 96% hitting the mark in May or June makes me wonder whether I should re-evaluate my model to better account for the faster rise and fall of cases, and therefore tests. [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE/edit#gid=1073567897
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1009791

2.5M as of 4/10, tracking @ ~150K/day, anticipate acceleration, so estimating average of 250K/day, 15M-2.5M=12.5M @ 250K/day = 50 days, which lands right at end of May (5/30). Slightly higher confidence for June than May because more likely to take longer than go faster.
